issues.description: The template's Stock class defines findStockIngredient(String name, boolean caseSensitive) (two parameters) but all uses in the same class (add, take) call findStockIngredient(String) (one parameter). This is an inner-template structural contradiction and also mismatches the problem statement UML and the solution, both of which expect findStockIngredient(String) with a single parameter. As written the template will not compile and will confuse students about the expected method signature and behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template Stock.findStockIngredient declaration to match the UML and solution: public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name) (single parameter). Alternatively, provide an overloaded one-argument version that delegates to the existing two-argument method (e.g., findStockIngredient(String name) calls findStockIngredient(name, true)) and document the intended case-sensitivity. Ensure add and take call the one-argument version or the appropriate overload so the code compiles and aligns with the problem statement.

issues.description: The problem statement's class diagram specifies Stock.findStockIngredient(String): StockIngredient (single-parameter). The solution implements findStockIngredient(String) (single-parameter) as expected. The template, however, declares findStockIngredient(String name, boolean caseSensitive) (two parameters). This creates a mismatch: students reading the diagram will expect a single-parameter method, the solution uses a single-parameter method, but the template exposes a different signature which also does not match how other template methods call it (add/take call findStockIngredient(ingredient) with a single argument). This inconsistency can cause confusion mapping the diagram to the starter code and may lead to compilation issues or unnecessary cognitive load when students try to locate/implement the expected method.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template with the problem diagram and the solution by providing a single-parameter findStockIngredient(String name) method. Options: (a) change the existing template method signature to findStockIngredient(String name) and implement the intended lookup, or (b) add an overloaded convenience method findStockIngredient(String name) that delegates to the two-argument version with a sensible default for case sensitivity. This will remove ambiguity and prevent compilation/mapping issues.
